sub_topic: Finding the Ramsey number of a graph.
message_1: What is the Ramsey number R(3,3) of a graph?
message_2:
The Ramsey number R(m, n) is the smallest integer R such that any graph with R vertices will contain either a clique of size m (a complete subgraph with m vertices) or an independent set of size n (a set of n vertices with no edges between them).

For R(3,3), it represents the smallest number of vertices in a graph such that there is either a clique of size 3 (a triangle) or an independent set of size 3.

The Ramsey number R(3,3) is 6. This means that in any graph with 6 vertices, there must be either a triangle (a complete subgraph with 3 vertices) or an independent set of 3 vertices with no edges between them.
